title: Quiz 4: Intake, Metabolism & Excretion
description: Assessment covering The Respiratory System (Ch 10), Nutrition (Ch 11), The Digestive System (Ch 12), and The Urinary System (Ch 13). Focuses on gas exchange, digestion, nutrient metabolism, and renal function.

questions.question: Where does the majority of nutrient absorption take place in the digestive tract?
questions.explanation: The small intestine (particularly the jejunum and ileum), with its villi and microvilli, provides a massive surface area for the absorption of nutrients. The stomach absorbs mainly alcohol and aspirin; the large intestine absorbs water.
questions.hint: It is the longest part of the alimentary canal.

questions.question: Match the digestive enzyme with the nutrient it breaks down:
questions.explanation: Amylase=Carbs. Pepsin/Trypsin=Proteins. Lipase=Fats.
questions.hint: Lip- for Lipids; Pep- for Peptides/Proteins.

questions.question: Arrange the path of urine flow from formation to excretion.
questions.explanation: Kidney (Nephron -> Pelvis) -> Ureter -> Bladder -> Urethra.
questions.hint: Kidney out to the world.

questions.question: Which of the following are functions of the LIVER? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Storage of glycogen, iron, and vitamins
Synthesis of plasma proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors)

questions.explanation: The liver produces bile, stores nutrients, synthesizes proteins, and detoxifies blood. Absorption happens in the small intestine, not the liver (though the liver processes what is absorbed).
questions.hint: The liver is a chemical factory, not an absorption tube.

questions.question: The functional unit of the kidney responsible for forming urine is called the ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: There are about 1 million nephrons in each kidney.
questions.hint: Starts with 'N'.

questions.question: What is the primary stimulus for the central chemoreceptors to increase the respiratory rate?
questions.explanation: Central chemoreceptors in the medulla are most sensitive to H+ ions derived from CO2 levels in the CSF. Increased CO2 (Hypercapnia) is the strongest drive to breathe in healthy people.
questions.hint: It's the waste product, not the fuel.

questions.question: What is the term for the wave-like muscular contractions that propel food through the digestive tract?
questions.explanation: Peristalsis involves alternating contraction and relaxation of smooth muscle to move contents forward.
questions.hint: Starts with 'P'.

questions.question: Gas exchange in the lungs occurs across the respiratory membrane in the bronchioles.
questions.explanation: FALSE. Gas exchange occurs in the ALVEOLI. Bronchioles are conducting airways.
questions.hint: Bronchioles have walls too thick for diffusion.

questions.question: Review the table on lung volumes. Which volume represents the 'amount of air moved in and out of the lungs during a normal quiet breath'?

richContent.content:
VolumeApprox. Amount
A500 mL
B3000 mL
C1200 mL

questions.explanation: Tidal Volume (TV) is the normal breath (~500mL). Residual volume is what's left after maximal expiration.
questions.hint: Like the tides coming in and out regularly.

questions.question: Match the vitamin deficiency with its associated disease:
questions.explanation: C=Collagen/Scurvy. D=Bones/Rickets. B12=Blood/Nerves. A=Eyes.
questions.hint: Sailors got Scurvy from lack of citrus (Vitamin C).

questions.question: Which of the following processes occur in the nephron during urine formation? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Selective Reabsorption (from tubule back to blood)

questions.explanation: Urine formation involves Filtration, Reabsorption, and Secretion. Emulsification happens to fats in the digestive tract.
questions.hint: Three key steps in the kidney.

questions.question: Order the parts of the small intestine from the stomach to the large intestine.
questions.explanation: Stomach -> Duodenum (shortest) -> Jejunum -> Ileum (longest) -> Large Intestine.
questions.hint: DJ I.

questions.question: What is the function of Bile?

options.text: To emulsify fats (break large globules into small droplets)
To secrete acid in the stomach

questions.explanation: Bile (produced by liver, stored in gallbladder) emulsifies fats, increasing the surface area for lipase enzymes to work. It does not contain digestive enzymes itself.
questions.hint: It acts like a detergent on grease.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ sphincter controls the exit of food from the stomach into the duodenum.
questions.explanation: The pyloric sphincter is at the bottom of the stomach. The cardiac (lower esophageal) sphincter is at the top.
questions.hint: Starts with 'P'.

questions.question: Which respiratory condition is characterized by the destruction of alveolar walls and loss of lung elasticity, leading to air trapping ('barrel chest')?
questions.explanation: Emphysema involves structural destruction of alveoli and loss of elasticity. Bronchitis is inflammation/mucus. Asthma is reversible constriction.
questions.hint: Part of COPD associated with structural damage.

questions.question: Name the specific hormone, secreted by the posterior pituitary, that increases water reabsorption in the kidney collecting ducts.
questions.explanation: ADH (Antidiuretic Hormone) makes the collecting ducts permeable to water, reducing urine volume.
questions.hint: Anti-urine hormone.

questions.question: Essential amino acids are those that the body can synthesize on its own.
questions.explanation: FALSE. Essential amino acids CANNOT be made by the body and MUST be obtained from the diet. Non-essential ones can be synthesized by the body.
questions.hint: If it's 'essential' to buy, you can't make it at home.

questions.question: Match the layer of the digestive tract wall with its function:

pairs.right: Connective tissue with blood vessels and nerves

questions.explanation: Mucosa=Inner/Functional. Submucosa=Support/Vessels. Muscularis=Movement. Serosa=Outer.
questions.hint: Mucus is inside; Muscle moves it.

questions.question: Which of the following occur during INSPIRATION (breathing in)? (Select all that apply)

options.text: External intercostal muscles contract (ribs move up/out)
Intrapulmonary pressure drops below atmospheric pressure

questions.explanation: Muscles contract -> Volume increases -> Pressure decreases -> Air flows IN.
questions.hint: Think about expanding the chest to suck air in.

questions.question: What is the Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) in a healthy adult?
questions.explanation: Normal GFR is approx 125 mL/min (180 L/day). Only about 1-1.5 L is excreted as urine; the rest is reabsorbed.
questions.hint: It's a specific rate per minute.

questions.question: Arrange the layers of the tooth from the outside in.
questions.explanation: Enamel is the hard outer layer. Dentine is the main body. Pulp contains the nerves/vessels inside.
questions.hint: Hardest to softest.

questions.question: In the stomach, which cells secrete Hydrochloric Acid (HCl)?
questions.explanation: Parietal cells secrete HCl and Intrinsic Factor. Chief cells secrete Pepsinogen.
questions.hint: Parietal = pH (acid).

questions.question: What is the name of the flap of cartilage that closes over the larynx during swallowing to prevent food from entering the airway?
questions.explanation: The epiglottis acts as a lid, diverting food into the esophagus and away from the trachea.
questions.hint: Starts with 'E'.

questions.question: Which of the following are constituents of normal urine? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Urine normally contains water, urea, uric acid, creatinine, and electrolytes. Glucose and blood cells should NOT be present in healthy urine.
questions.hint: Think about what the body wants to keep (sugar, blood) vs get rid of (waste).

questions.question: Internal respiration refers to the exchange of gases between the lungs (alveoli) and the blood.
questions.explanation: FALSE. Internal respiration is exchange between blood and TISSUES. External respiration is exchange between lungs and blood.
questions.hint: Internal happens deep inside the tissues.

questions.question: Match the respiratory term with its definition:

pairs.right: High carbon dioxide levels in the blood

questions.explanation: Hypo=Low O2. Hyper=High CO2. Dys=Difficult. A=No breath.
questions.hint: Use the prefixes/suffixes.

questions.question: What is the function of the Intrinsic Factor secreted by the stomach?
questions.explanation: Intrinsic factor is essential for the absorption of Vitamin B12 in the ileum. Lack of it causes Pernicious Anaemia.
questions.hint: It binds to a vitamin.

questions.question: A BMI (Body Mass Index) greater than ___BLANK___ is classified as obese.
questions.explanation: BMI > 25 is Overweight. BMI > 30 is Obese.
questions.hint: It's a round number starting with 3.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of the kidneys?
questions.explanation: The LIVER produces urea (from protein breakdown). The kidneys EXCRETE it. Kidneys do regulate BP, electrolytes, and produce EPO.
questions.hint: Where is protein metabolized?

questions.question: Identify the accessory organs of the digestive system. (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Accessory organs lie outside the alimentary canal but secrete into it. The stomach is part of the main tract.
questions.hint: Which ones does food NOT pass through?
